title: How I Travel With Breast Cancer and Other Health Conditions

content: I recently traveled alone for the first time after my diagnosis. I won’t lie, the anxiety was running high; however, I was able to overcome all those feelings mostly by breath work and, of course, checking my bags at least a couple of times just to make sure I wasn’t leaving anything I needed behind. In addition to breast cancer, I have type 1 diabetes and adrenal insufficiency.  Both are considered to be chemically induced and permanent due to the immunotherapy I received for cancer treatment.  So my traveling checklist consists of the following items:

I make sure I take enough medication and supplies not only to account for the days I’m traveling but also in case of an emergency and I get stuck anywhere for a couple of extra days. These are the very first things I pack, and I make sure to account for everything again before I leave my house. It is extremely important that I am aware of medical centers or hospitals wherever I travel in case of an emergency. It’s also important that when I get to my destination or beforehand, I exchange emergency contact information with the people I will be visiting or staying with.
bullets: Pump supplies for pump site changes
Dexcom sensor, extra transmitter, and over patch
Blood sugar meter, test strips, and lancets

content: Along with ensuring I have the necessary medications and medical supplies; I ensure that I have clothes that have pockets and are able to hook my pump onto. Since I request a pat down in the airport instead of going through the X-ray machine because of the medical devices I carry on me, I always make sure I have more than enough time and that I travel with very comfortable clothes and shoes on.

Since I make sure to arrive at the airport early, I always plan to have a good breakfast there. I do this so that I can manage my sugar at a healthy level. I have neuropathy in my hands, so it’s sometimes hard for me to carry or grip my luggage. If I need assistance, I make sure to ask the airline for assistance or check my luggage so that I don’t have to carry anything. One thing I do have to say is that I always have my backpack, which contains all my medication and medical supplies. That I do not and will not check. It’s important for me to have immediate access to it. I also stay in constant communication with my loved ones so that they know how I am doing.

content: Lastly, if you are traveling, make sure to consult with your doctor, and most of all, have fun. It can be stressful, but at the end of the day, make sure to enjoy your trip. I love getting a window seat because I get to view how beautiful the Earth is from way up in the sky.
